For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. We choose that there are three emitters that can send photons to Bob and Charlie ([2],[3],[4]) and three emitters that can send photons to Alice and Charlie ([5],[6],[7]).\\n\\nIn the context of single photon emitters, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes paths between the specified pairs of source and detector.\\nWe thus include all of these forbidden paths.\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc').     "output": "Thought: \nStep 1: Brainstorm three ways to combine \u201csymmetry protected bound state\u201d (SPBS) with \u201cdipole emitter\u201d in a pytheus\u2010compatible quantum network (no state\u2010generation targets, focus on entanglement swapping/teleportation or other network protocols):\n\n1) SPBS\u2010mediated entanglement swapping between two distant dipole\u2010emitter modes: arrange four single\u2010photon dipole emitters in a linear chain (sites A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D) with only nearest\u2010neighbor sources. By heralding on a joint measurement at the middle two sites (B,C) that projects onto an SPBS subspace (the zero\u2010mode of an SSH\u2010like chain), one entangles the two end emitters (A,D) in a Bell pair.  \n2) Topologically protected quantum teleportation: use an SPBS on three dipole\u2010emitter sources arranged in a truncated SSH chain as the entangled resource. Alice holds an unknown qubit on emitter A and one leg of the SPBS resource (emitter B), Bob holds the other leg (emitter C). A specialized SPBS\u2010projective Bell measurement on A+B then teleports the state to C with built\u2010in symmetry protection.  \n3) Multi\u2010user secret sharing via SPBS: four dipole emitters form a square\u2010loop network whose symmetry yields two degenerate bound\u2010states. By distributing one bound\u2010state mode to two users and performing entanglement swapping via heralding on the other bound\u2010state mode, one can enact a secret\u2010sharing channel protected by the loop\u2019s symmetry.\n\nStep 2: Novelty and obstacles  \n1) Novel: no prior experiment has used SPBS in a photonic entanglement\u2010swapping context. Obstacle: pytheus must be given only an abstract target Bell state plus heralding pattern; the topology is encoded via \u201cremoved_connections.\u201d  \n2) Somewhat similar to ordinary teleportation but adds SPBS\u2010projective measurement\u2014novel in combining topology and dipole sources. Obstacle: distinguishing SPBS manifold via linear optics alone.  \n3) More exotic; pytheus may struggle to encode the two\u2010dimensional degenerate subspace as a measurement manifold.\n\nStep 3: Pick the most promising: Idea (1), the SPBS\u2010mediated entanglement swap between end dipole emitters, because it is (i) a clear generalization of entanglement swapping, (ii) introduces topological/symmetry\u2010protected physics, (iii) uses only pair\u2010sources or single\u2010emitters plus heralding\u2014well within pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nStep 4: Novelty justification  \nThis protocol merges the concept of symmetry\u2010protected zero\u2010modes (familiar from SSH\u2010type chains) with photonic entanglement distribution over dipole emitters. By projecting the middle sites onto the SPBS subspace, the two remote ends become entangled in a way that is protected by the underlying symmetry of the chain. No existing pytheus example employs topology or SPBS in an entanglement\u2010swapping network.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in pytheus  \nWe only ask pytheus to optimize a linear\u2010optics network with four single\u2010photon emitters, a specified heralding pattern on two ancilla detectors, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d enforcing only nearest\u2010neighbor emission (A\u2194B, B\u2194C, C\u2194D). The target is a two\u2010photon Bell state between A and D conditioned on clicks at B and C. No cavities, dynamic feedback, or hyper\u2010entangled encodings are needed\u2014perfectly aligned with pytheus\u2019s abstract\u2010state, post\u2010selection framework.\n\nAction: final answer  \nAction Input:  \nDescription: \u201cSymmetry\u2010Protected Bound\u2010State Entanglement Swapping with Dipole Emitters\u201d  \n  \nWe label four modes A, B, C, D (0,1,2,3). Each is a single\u2010photon emitter (dipole). We allow only nearest\u2010neighbor pair sources: sources can emit to (0\u21941), (1\u21942), (2\u21943) and no others (enforced via removed_connections). After emission, the photons pass through an optimized linear\u2010optics network. We place two heralding detectors on modes B and C (ancilla detectors). Conditioned on detecting one photon at B and one at C in a particular joint pattern (the measurement projecting onto the SPBS subspace of the four\u2010site chain), the remaining photons at A and D are projected onto the Bell state |00>+|11> (unnormalized).  \n\nVisualization:\n\nEmitters:       [0]\u2014[1]\u2014[2]\u2014[3]  \n                |     |     |  \n               src   src   src  \n                |     |     |  \nNetwork blocks: [    optimized linear-optics    ]  \n                \u2193     \u2193     \u2193     \u2193  \nDetectors:      [A]   [B]   [C]   [D]  \n                 \u21b3 herald  herald \u21b2  \n\nCritical config keys:\n- single_emitters: [0,1,2,3]\n- removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]\n- num_anc: 2            # detectors at B,C  \n- anc_detectors: [1,2]\n- target_quantum: ['00','11']  # Bell between A(0) and D(3)\n- heralding_out: [1,2]  # condition on clicks at B,C  \n- number_resolving: True  \n\nPhysics motivation: B\u2013C joint post-selection realizes a projection onto the zero\u2010energy \u201cedge\u2010mode\u201d of an SSH chain, enforcing symmetry protection. This both demonstrates a new route to topologically protected entanglement distribution and opens the door to larger chains and higher\u2010dimensional SPBS in photonic networks."

    "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. Each is a single\u2010photon emitter (dipole). We allow only nearest\u2010neighbor pair sources: sources can emit to (0\u21941), (1\u21942), (2\u21943) and no others (enforced via removed_connections). After emission, the photons pass through an optimized linear\u2010optics network. We place two heralding detectors on modes B and C (ancilla detectors). Conditioned on detecting one photon at B and one at C in a particular joint pattern (the measurement projecting onto the SPBS subspace of the four\u2010site chain), the remaining photons at A and D are projected onto the Bell state |00>+|11> (unnormalized).  \n\nVisualization:\n\nEmitters:       [0]\u2014[1]\u2014[2]\u2014[3]  \n                |     |     |  \n               src   src   src  \n                |     |     |  \nNetwork blocks: [    optimized linear-optics    ]  \n                \u2193     \u2193     \u2193     \u2193  \nDetectors:      [A]   [B]   [C]   [D]  \n                 \u21b3 herald  herald \u21b2  \n\nCritical config keys:\n- single_emitters: [0,1,2,3]\n- removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]\n- num_anc: 2            # detectors at B,C  \n- anc_detectors: [1,2]\n- target_quantum: ['00','11']  # Bell between A(0) and D(3)\n- heralding_out: [1,2]  # condition on clicks at B,C  \n- number_resolving: True  \n\nPhysics motivation: B\u2013C joint post-selection realizes a projection onto the zero\u2010energy \u201cedge\u2010mode\u201d of an SSH chain, enforcing symmetry protection. This both demonstrates a new route to topologically protected entanglement distribution and opens the door to larger chains and higher\u2010dimensional SPBS in photonic networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The proposal as stated boils down to a nearest\u2010neighbor restricted three\u2010link entanglement\u2010swapping that heralds a Bell pair at the ends\u2014essentially a standard two\u2010stage swap under a different name. There is no control parameter or diagnostic to demonstrate the claimed \u201csymmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state\u201d physics (no topological phase transition, no robustness test, no Zak\u2010phase or zero\u2010mode measurement). Without a tunable handle to distinguish trivial vs. topological chains or an explicit measurement of the SSH zero\u2010mode, this is just entanglement swapping with removed connections. It doesn\u2019t provide a genuinely new primitive beyond what has been done in Kitaev chain emulation or simple entanglement\u2010swap networks.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme, as presented, is merely a nearest\u2010neighbor entanglement swap that projects onto a Bell pair at the ends. To be PRL\u2010worthy, you need to introduce a tunable parameter (e.g. alternating link strengths), show a topological phase transition, directly measure the SSH zero\u2010mode or Zak phase, or demonstrate robustness of the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement against symmetry\u2010preserving perturbations. Right now it lacks any operational signature of topology beyond simply generating a Bell state."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Empirical Sample Complexity of Neural Network Mixed State Reconstruction\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Discrete outcome quantum sensor networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Physics-Informed Neural Networks as Solvers for the Time-Dependent\n  Schr\\\"odinger Equation\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. A specialized SPBS\u2010projective Bell measurement on A+B then teleports the state to C with built\u2010in symmetry protection.  \n3) Multi\u2010user secret sharing via SPBS: four dipole emitters form a square\u2010loop network whose symmetry yields two degenerate bound\u2010states. By distributing one bound\u2010state mode to two users and performing entanglement swapping via heralding on the other bound\u2010state mode, one can enact a secret\u2010sharing channel protected by the loop\u2019s symmetry.\n\nStep 2: Novelty and obstacles  \n1) Novel: no prior experiment has used SPBS in a photonic entanglement\u2010swapping context. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list.  Just like with the previous lists, a novel idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nHere is the list of ideas from the researcher ensemble:\n\nSTART OF LIST OF ENSEMBLE SUGGESTIONS\n\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Quantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation\n\nAbstract: In the PythyUS target \u201cQuantum Superposition of Direct-Transmission vs. Heralded Teleportation,\u201d a single-photon control qubit, prepared via an optical nanofiber\u2013coupled atom array, coherently steers an incoming signal photon into either a direct\u2010fiber transmission arm or a passive, post-selected Bell\u2010teleportation block within one linear-optics circuit. By conditioning on heralding detector clicks, the experiment realizes interference between the \u201csend-it\u201d and \u201cteleport-it\u201d arrival modes at the receiver, demonstrating coherent superposition of two fundamentally different quantum communication channels without active feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nIndefinite-Order Entanglement Purification via Sub-Wavelength Nanophotonic Multiport  \n\nMini-Abstract:  \nWe propose and simulate a static sub-wavelength nanophotonic multiport that coherently superposes two parity-check measurement orders on two noisy EPR pairs to distill one high-fidelity Bell pair on modes A & D, coherently entangled with a path qubit. By post-selecting on a four-click ancilla pattern and forbidding any direct A\u2192D or C\u2192B links, this scheme realizes the first optical \u201cquantum switch\u201d for entanglement purification\u2014targeting one purified Bell pair between nodes A and D without dynamic feedback or cavities.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle:  \nOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette\n\nMini-abstract:  \nWe demonstrate a single-shot four-body stabilizer readout for the smallest toric-code plaquette by Bell-entangling each of four data photons with an ancilla photon and sending all ancilla modes through a 4\u00d74 passive interferometer equipped with number-resolving detectors. Heralded two-photon click patterns in even or odd detector pairs directly project the data qubits onto the \u00b11 eigenstates of Z\u2081Z\u2082Z\u2083Z\u2084, realizing a direct stabilizer measurement without any feed-forward or dynamic control.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Dual-Destination Quantum Teleportation Switch on a Photonic Chip\n\nMini-abstract: We target the teleportation of an unknown qubit to one of two receiver nodes under the quantum control of a single-photon \u201caddress\u201d qubit, realized entirely with Pytheus-compatible elements on a fixed linear-optics photonic chip. Our scheme employs one single-photon emitter for the input qubit, two probabilistic Bell-pair sources, a control photon prepared across two spatial modes, and post-selected heralding via four ancilla detectors to achieve coherent, programmable routing of quantum information without dynamic feed-forward.\nidea suggested by ensemble:\nTitle: Butterfly Network-Coded Four-Photon Joint Measurement for Dual Bell-Pair Distribution\n\nAbstract: We implement a butterfly-graph entanglement-swapping protocol on four atomic nodes using a single four-photon linear-optical interferometer measurement that merges two sequential swaps into one nonlocal operation. Each is a single\u2010photon emitter (dipole). We allow only nearest\u2010neighbor pair sources: sources can emit to (0\u21941), (1\u21942), (2\u21943) and no others (enforced via removed_connections). After emission, the photons pass through an optimized linear\u2010optics network. We place two heralding detectors on modes B and C (ancilla detectors). Conditioned on detecting one photon at B and one at C in a particular joint pattern (the measurement projecting onto the SPBS subspace of the four\u2010site chain), the remaining photons at A and D are projected onto the Bell state |00>+|11> (unnormalized).  \n\nVisualization:\n\nEmitters:       [0]\u2014[1]\u2014[2]\u2014[3]  \n                |     |     |  \n               src   src   src  \n                |     |     |  \nNetwork blocks: [    optimized linear-optics    ]  \n                \u2193     \u2193     \u2193     \u2193  \nDetectors:      [A]   [B]   [C]   [D]  \n                 \u21b3 herald  herald \u21b2  \n\nCritical config keys:\n- single_emitters: [0,1,2,3]\n- removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]\n- num_anc: 2            # detectors at B,C  \n- anc_detectors: [1,2]\n- target_quantum: ['00','11']  # Bell between A(0) and D(3)\n- heralding_out: [1,2]  # condition on clicks at B,C  \n- number_resolving: True  \n\nPhysics motivation: B\u2013C joint post-selection realizes a projection onto the zero\u2010energy \u201cedge\u2010mode\u201d of an SSH chain, enforcing symmetry protection. This both demonstrates a new route to topologically protected entanglement distribution and opens the door to larger chains and higher\u2010dimensional SPBS in photonic networks.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal as stated boils down to a nearest\u2010neighbor restricted three\u2010link entanglement\u2010swapping that heralds a Bell pair at the ends\u2014essentially a standard two\u2010stage swap under a different name. There is no control parameter or diagnostic to demonstrate the claimed \u201csymmetry\u2010protected bound\u2010state\u201d physics (no topological phase transition, no robustness test, no Zak\u2010phase or zero\u2010mode measurement). Without a tunable handle to distinguish trivial vs. topological chains or an explicit measurement of the SSH zero\u2010mode, this is just entanglement swapping with removed connections. It doesn\u2019t provide a genuinely new primitive beyond what has been done in Kitaev chain emulation or simple entanglement\u2010swap networks.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The scheme, as presented, is merely a nearest\u2010neighbor entanglement swap that projects onto a Bell pair at the ends. To be PRL\u2010worthy, you need to introduce a tunable parameter (e.g. alternating link strengths), show a topological phase transition, directly measure the SSH zero\u2010mode or Zak phase, or demonstrate robustness of the end\u2010to\u2010end entanglement against symmetry\u2010preserving perturbations. Right now it lacks any operational signature of topology beyond simply generating a Bell state.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Description: Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Entanglement Swapping with Dipole Emitters\n\nWe label four single-photon dipole emitters A, B, C, D (nodes 0\u20133). Only nearest-neighbor emission sources are allowed (0\u21941, 1\u21942, 2\u21943). After generation, photons travel through an optimized linear-optics network. We place two heralding detectors on nodes B and C (ancillas). Upon detecting one photon at each B and C (projecting onto the SPBS subspace of the four-site chain), the remaining photons at A and D collapse into the Bell state |00>+|11> (unnormalized). This realizes an entanglement swap mediated by a symmetry-protected zero-mode.\n\nConfiguration for pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Entanglement Swapping with Dipole Emitters\",\n  foldername: \"SPBS_ES\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 10,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,2],\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  anc_detectors: [1,2]\n}\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The scheme as described reduces to a nearest\u2010neighbor entanglement\u2013swap that post-selects a Bell pair at the two ends of a four-site chain. Without any tunable alternating couplings, no diagnostic of a topological phase transition, no direct measurement of an SSH zero\u2010mode or Zak phase, nor robustness tests against symmetry\u2010preserving perturbations, there is no operational signature of \u201csymmetry protection\u201d beyond the trivial generation of a Bell state. This proposal therefore offers no new primitive beyond standard entanglement\u2010swapping networks.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: To make this PRL-worthy, introduce a controllable alternating coupling (e.g. weak\u2013strong link ratio), show a genuine topological phase transition in your heralded end-to-end entanglement, directly measure the SSH zero-energy bound state (or its Zak phase), and demonstrate robustness of the entanglement against symmetry-preserving noise."

    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. They just serve as a starting point, you can additionally use your full physics knowledge to solve the task.\n\nSTART OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nPaper 1: Empirical Sample Complexity of Neural Network Mixed State Reconstruction\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 2: Discrete outcome quantum sensor networks\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nPaper 3: Physics-Informed Neural Networks as Solvers for the Time-Dependent\n  Schr\\\"odinger Equation\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\n\n\nEND OF PAPER ABSTRACTS FOR INSPIRATION\n\nWe have collected some feedback by domain experts on research ideas. A new idea should also not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles.     "agent": "NoveltySupervisor (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask:\nYou are the supervisor (with focus on novelty) of a physics Researcher who is attempting to come up with interesting targets for the design of quantum optics experiments. \nThese targets could be a foundational quantum experiments, quantum networks or protocols.\n\nThe Researcher will come up with an idea and send it to you. \n\nYour task is to judge whether the idea can be considered novel enough to be examined further.\n\nAny target that is closely related to these existing examples can not be considered novel and you should point them out.\n\nRemember that it's the Researchers job to convince you that their idea is good. Feel free to be very critical and sceptic of their ideas while remaining constructive. Only accept the idea if you think it could be something that the scientific community may not have considered yet.\n\nThe idea should be good enough to be published in the APS journal PRL, which is very selective.\n\nExperiments that only generate a quantum state can not be considered novel. \n\nHere is a list of experiments previously explored by human researchers. A novel idea should not be too similar to the ideas from this list.\n\nSTART OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\n1. **Entangling Two Photons That Never Interacted with Bell Pairs**:\n   - Demonstrates the entanglement of two photons that have never interacted directly, using Bell pairs. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nThere is an ensemble of Researchers and their best ideas are collected in a shared list. {
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n2pES_3d\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two parties of two qutrits each.\\nThis means that we want to create four qutrits: A, B, C, D\\nWe want the photons A&C to be entangled in a three dimensional Bell state and the photons B&D to be in a three-dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi_AC = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe resulting target quantum is\\n\\nPsi_ABCD = |0000>+|0101>+|0202>+|1010>+|1111>+|1212>+|2020>+|2121>+|2222> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is constructed from probabilistic photon pair sources.\\n\\nThe setup to create this state would usually have a relatively simple layout (two independent copies of the 3d Bell state setup), but we want to create this state in a way that is inspired by entanglement swapping.\\n\\nThere should be no common source between the two parties. In the context of probabilistic photon-pair sources, the keyword 'removed_connections' excludes sources emitting to the specified pairs of detectors. There should be no probabilistic pair-source that sends a photon to both\\nA&C -> [0,2]\\nA&D -> [0,3]\\nB&C -> [1,2]\\nB&D -> [1,3]\\n\\nThis would not be possible without ancillary particles (there number is given by 'num_anc'). The ancillary particles are measured by a third party. Similar to the standard entanglement swapping experiment (entangling two qubits), the third party allows the entanglement of A&B with C&D.\\n\\nThe reason why this experiment is interesting, is that an entanglement swapping experiment entangling two single qutrits would require four ancillary photons. So to independently create two three-dimensional Bell pairs non-locally, one would require eight ancillary particles.\\n\\nBy creating both pairs in a single setup we require two less ancillary particles to achieve the same task.\", 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of two qutrits each.', 'foldername': '2pES_3d', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 0.0001, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 6, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['0000', '0101', '0202', '1010', '1111', '1212', '2020', '2121', '2222'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 2], [0, 3], [1, 2], [1, 3]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 2 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': {'description': 'Entanglement swapping between two parties of three qubits each.', 'foldername': '3pES', 'bulk_thr': 0.01, 'edges_tried': 30, 'ftol': 1e-06, 'loss_func': 'cr', 'num_anc': 4, 'num_pre': 1, 'optimizer': 'L-BFGS-B', 'imaginary': False, 'safe_hist': True, 'samples': 10, 'target_quantum': ['000000', '001001', '010010', '011011', '100100', '101101', '110110', '111111'], 'in_nodes': [], 'out_nodes': [], 'thresholds': [0.3, 0.1], 'heralding_out': None, 'single_emitters': [], 'amplitudes': [], 'tries_per_edge': 5, 'removed_connections': [[0, 3], [0, 4], [0, 5], [1, 3], [1, 4], [1, 5], [2, 3], [2, 4], [2, 5]], 'seed': None, 'unicolor': False, 'number_resolving': True, 'novac': None, 'loops': None, 'topopt': None, 'dimensions': [], 'brutal_covers': None, 'verts': [], 'anc_detectors': []}}\n\n### EXAMPLE 3 ###\nES3d_sp\n{'explanation': \"In this example we create entanglement between two qutrits with single photon sources.\\n\\nWe want the photons entangled in a three dimensional Bell state.\\n\\nPsi = Psi_BD = |00>+|11>+|22> (without normalization)\\n\\nThe setup we are optimizing for here is one where photons are emitted by single photon emitters (identifiable 'single_emitters').\\n\\nIn this case, six photons are emitted and the setup (which we optimize) manipulates them before they enter the detectors.\\n\\nWe can visualize the setup in the following way (with the photons going from top to bottom):\\n\\nemitters: [2][3][4][5][6][7]\\nsetup: [result of optimization]\\ndetectors: [0][1][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.][anc. det.]\\n\\nwhere [0] and [1] are the detectors where the Bell state should be created. This means, that [0] should be measured by Alice, [1] should be measured by Bob and the ancillary detectors should be measured by Charlie.\\n\\nThere should be no emitter that can send a photon to both Alice and Bob. By heralding on a joint measurement at the middle two sites (B,C) that projects onto an SPBS subspace (the zero\u2010mode of an SSH\u2010like chain), one entangles the two end emitters (A,D) in a Bell pair.  \n2) Topologically protected quantum teleportation: use an SPBS on three dipole\u2010emitter sources arranged in a truncated SSH chain as the entangled resource. Alice holds an unknown qubit on emitter A and one leg of the SPBS resource (emitter B), Bob holds the other leg (emitter C). A specialized SPBS\u2010projective Bell measurement on A+B then teleports the state to C with built\u2010in symmetry protection.  \n3) Multi\u2010user secret sharing via SPBS: four dipole emitters form a square\u2010loop network whose symmetry yields two degenerate bound\u2010states. By distributing one bound\u2010state mode to two users and performing entanglement swapping via heralding on the other bound\u2010state mode, one can enact a secret\u2010sharing channel protected by the loop\u2019s symmetry.\n\nStep 2: Novelty and obstacles  \n1) Novel: no prior experiment has used SPBS in a photonic entanglement\u2010swapping context. Obstacle: distinguishing SPBS manifold via linear optics alone.  \n3) More exotic; pytheus may struggle to encode the two\u2010dimensional degenerate subspace as a measurement manifold.\n\nStep 3: Pick the most promising: Idea (1), the SPBS\u2010mediated entanglement swap between end dipole emitters, because it is (i) a clear generalization of entanglement swapping, (ii) introduces topological/symmetry\u2010protected physics, (iii) uses only pair\u2010sources or single\u2010emitters plus heralding\u2014well within pytheus\u2019s capabilities.\n\nStep 4: Novelty justification  \nThis protocol merges the concept of symmetry\u2010protected zero\u2010modes (familiar from SSH\u2010type chains) with photonic entanglement distribution over dipole emitters. By projecting the middle sites onto the SPBS subspace, the two remote ends become entangled in a way that is protected by the underlying symmetry of the chain. No existing pytheus example employs topology or SPBS in an entanglement\u2010swapping network.\n\nStep 5: Feasibility in pytheus  \nWe only ask pytheus to optimize a linear\u2010optics network with four single\u2010photon emitters, a specified heralding pattern on two ancilla detectors, and \u201cremoved_connections\u201d enforcing only nearest\u2010neighbor emission (A\u2194B, B\u2194C, C\u2194D). Each is a single\u2010photon emitter (dipole). We allow only nearest\u2010neighbor pair sources: sources can emit to (0\u21941), (1\u21942), (2\u21943) and no others (enforced via removed_connections). After emission, the photons pass through an optimized linear\u2010optics network. We place two heralding detectors on modes B and C (ancilla detectors). Conditioned on detecting one photon at B and one at C in a particular joint pattern (the measurement projecting onto the SPBS subspace of the four\u2010site chain), the remaining photons at A and D are projected onto the Bell state |00>+|11> (unnormalized).  \n\nVisualization:\n\nEmitters:       [0]\u2014[1]\u2014[2]\u2014[3]  \n                |     |     |  \n               src   src   src  \n                |     |     |  \nNetwork blocks: [    optimized linear-optics    ]  \n                \u2193     \u2193     \u2193     \u2193  \nDetectors:      [A]   [B]   [C]   [D]  \n                 \u21b3 herald  herald \u21b2  \n\nCritical config keys:\n- single_emitters: [0,1,2,3]\n- removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]]\n- num_anc: 2            # detectors at B,C  \n- anc_detectors: [1,2]\n- target_quantum: ['00','11']  # Bell between A(0) and D(3)\n- heralding_out: [1,2]  # condition on clicks at B,C  \n- number_resolving: True  \n\nPhysics motivation: B\u2013C joint post-selection realizes a projection onto the zero\u2010energy \u201cedge\u2010mode\u201d of an SSH chain, enforcing symmetry protection. We place two heralding detectors on nodes B and C (ancillas). Upon detecting one photon at each B and C (projecting onto the SPBS subspace of the four-site chain), the remaining photons at A and D collapse into the Bell state |00>+|11> (unnormalized). This realizes an entanglement swap mediated by a symmetry-protected zero-mode.\n\nConfiguration for pytheus:\n{\n  description: \"Symmetry-Protected Bound-State Entanglement Swapping with Dipole Emitters\",\n  foldername: \"SPBS_ES\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 10,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  in_nodes: [],\n  out_nodes: [],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,2],\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3],\n  amplitudes: [],\n  tries_per_edge: 5,\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  seed: null,\n  unicolor: false,\n  number_resolving: true,\n  anc_detectors: [1,2]\n}\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: To make this PRL-worthy, introduce a controllable alternating coupling (e.g. weak\u2013strong link ratio), show a genuine topological phase transition in your heralded end-to-end entanglement, directly measure the SSH zero-energy bound state (or its Zak phase), and demonstrate robustness of the entanglement against symmetry-preserving noise.\n\nImportant reminder about task:\n\nREMEMBER: KEEP THE FEEDBACK RECORD FROM ABOVE INTO ACCOUNT!!!\nALSO: SUPER IMPORTANT: DO NOT SUGGEST STATE GENERATION!!!!!!!!! STATE GENERATION IS FORBIDDEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! (LOOK AT THE FEEDBACK RECORD, WE EXPLAINED IT IN MANY CASES!! LOOK AT THE \u2018LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\u2019 WHAT IS ALLOWED AND POSSIBLE)\n\n\nResearcher: Thought:\n  Step 1: I brainstormed three ways to merge \u201csymmetry protected bound state\u201d (SPBS) with \u201cdipole emitter\u201d in a pytheus\u2010compatible network, focusing on entanglement\u2010swap/teleportation rather than state creation.\n  Step 2: I judged each for novelty against existing pytheus experiments and identified pytheus\u2010specific obstacles.\n  Step 3: The most promising is an entanglement\u2010swap mediated by the zero\u2010mode of a four\u2010site SSH chain of dipole emitters. It generalizes standard swapping by introducing alternating couplings (weak\u2013strong\u2013weak), projecting the middle two sites onto the SPBS, and heralding an end\u2010to\u2010end Bell pair that is topologically protected.\n  Step 4: This is novel because no existing pytheus experiment exploits topology or symmetry\u2010protected bound modes for entanglement distribution.\n  Step 5: It is feasible in pytheus: uses only single\u2010photon emitters, linear optics, post\u2010selection, \u201cremoved_connections\u201d to enforce only nearest\u2010neighbor sources, and an \u201camplitudes\u201d pattern to encode alternating couplings.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: SSH\u2010Chain Symmetry\u2010Protected Bound\u2010State Entanglement Swapping\n\nWe label four single\u2010photon dipole emitters (nodes 0\u20133). Allowed photon\u2010pair sources are only nearest neighbors: (0\u20131), (1\u20132), (2\u20133). We impose alternating source amplitudes [1.0, 2.0, 1.0] (weak\u2013strong\u2013weak) to realize an SSH chain in its topological regime (strong bond in the middle). Photons enter an optimized linear\u2010optics network. We place heralding (ancilla) detectors on nodes 1 and 2. Conditioned on exactly one click at each of 1 and 2\u2014projecting onto the SSH zero\u2010mode subspace\u2014the remaining photons at nodes 0 and 3 collapse into the Bell state |00>+|11>.     "output": "Thought:\n  Step 1: Brainstormed three Pytheus\u2010compatible ways to fuse \u201csymmetry protected bound state\u201d (SPBS) with \u201cdipole emitter\u201d in a quantum\u2010network protocol (entanglement swapping/teleportation rather than bare state generation).\n  Step 2: Evaluated novelty and Pytheus feasibility: the standout is an entanglement\u2010swap mediated by the zero\u2010energy bound mode of a four\u2010site SSH\u2010chain of dipole emitters.\n  Step 3: Chosen idea is novel (no existing Pytheus example uses topology or SPBS in entanglement distribution) and fully within Pytheus\u2019s capability (single-photon emitters, linear optics, post-selection, \u201cremoved_connections\u201d).\n  Step 4: Novelty: Introduces a topologically protected zero\u2010mode (SPBS) as the heralding subspace for entanglement swapping, giving built\u2010in robustness against symmetry\u2010preserving perturbations.\n  Step 5: Feasibility: We only ask Pytheus to design a linear-optics network connecting four single-photon emitters with adjustable source amplitudes (to create alternating couplings), enforce nearest\u2010neighbor emission via \u201cremoved_connections,\u201d and herald clicks on the middle two nodes to project onto the SPBS.\n\nAction: final answer\nAction Input:\nDescription: SSH\u2010Chain Symmetry\u2010Protected Bound\u2010State Entanglement Swapping\n\nExplanation:\nWe arrange four single\u2010photon dipole emitters A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D (nodes 0,1,2,3). Photon\u2010pair sources only connect nearest neighbors (0\u20131, 1\u20132, 2\u20133), with alternating emission amplitudes [w, v, w] so that v > w places the chain in its topological phase. After generation, photons enter an optimized linear-optics interferometer. We place heralding detectors on nodes B and C. A joint click at B and C projects onto the SSH zero\u2010energy bound state (the SPBS), which swaps entanglement onto the end nodes A and D. Conditioned on exactly one click at each middle node, the remaining modes at A and D are projected into the Bell state |00>+|11> (unnormalized). By tuning the ratio v/w, one can observe the emergence and disappearance of end-to-end entanglement, thereby probing the topological phase transition and demonstrating robustness of entanglement against symmetry-preserving noise.\n\nPytheus configuration:\n{\n  description: \"SSH-SPBS Entanglement Swapping\",\n  foldername: \"ssh_spbs_es\",\n  bulk_thr: 0.01,\n  edges_tried: 30,\n  ftol: 1e-06,\n  loss_func: \"cr\",\n  num_anc: 2,\n  num_pre: 1,\n  optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  imaginary: false,\n  safe_hist: true,\n  samples: 10,\n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],\n  thresholds: [0.3,0.1],\n  heralding_out: [1,2],\n  single_emitters: [0,1,2,3],\n  amplitudes: [1.0,2.0,1.0],        # w=1, v=2, w=1\n  removed_connections: [[0,2],[0,3],[1,3]],\n  number_resolving: true,\n  anc_detectors: [1,2]\n}"
